text: HSBC is Europe's biggest bank and
employs 48,000 people in the UK today
that number is being cut by 8,000 it
means one in six staff who work for HSBC
here will lose their job over the next
two years why well it's because making
money from banking is much tougher now
the good times are over since the 2008
crisis the regulator's have to try to
ensure that banks don't make profits
just out of trading so a lot of the
trading for own profits means shut down
by the rules the bank wants to save 3.2
billion pounds so as well as cutting
back on staff they'll be closing
branches too now the chief executive of
HSBC Stuart Gulliver says we recognize
that the world has changed and we need
to change with it but the unions are
worried about what it will mean for
workers HSBC is one of the few employers
where there isn't a voluntary redundancy
scheme and we're going to be asking
demanding in fact for one to be
implemented for this change if we
understand it correctly the job losses
don't need to be made until the end of
2017 so there's a proper time for the
bank to really consider this the past
year has been one of the toughest in
HSBC's 150 year history with scandals
around tax evasion mis-selling financial
products and even the recent FIFA drama
is dragging HSBC's nib through the mud
this restructuring plan is the bank's
attempt to turn things around and
maximize profits
it's headquartered in London at the
moment but it's affected by specific
taxes in the UK which are problematic
for HSBC and also by British government
plans to ring-fence retail banks from
investment banks and that also affects
HSBC which runs a high street operation
as well as a global investment bank so
those are big costs for HSBC HSBC is
being trying to reduce its size for many
years now it wasn't that long ago that
it employed over 350,000 people now it's
260 thousand it's reduced the number of
countries that it operates in before the
financial crisis
banks were very keen to operate in
almost every country in the world
because making profits in banking pre
2007 and 2008 was frankly a much easier
job that has all changed now with new
regulations new capital requirements for
banks it means that making money in
countries is now difficult that means
you have to go for profit smaller easier
to manage
